##□□□□□□□□□□ □□□□□□□□□□□

The line of reflection is usually given in the form $y = mx + b$.

[[☃ explanation 1]]

□□□□ □□□□□ □□ □□□ □□□□□□□□ □□□□□□ □□ □□□ □□□□ □□□□□□□□□□□□□ □□□□□□□□ □□□□ □□□ □□□□ □□ □□□□□□□□□□ □□ □□□ □□□□□□□□□□□□□ □□□□□ □□ □□□ □□□□□.

**□□□□□□□:**

Reflect $\overline{PQ}$ over the line $y=x$.  

First, we must find the line of reflection $y=x$. The slope is $1$ and the $y$ intercept is $0$.

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/8292f35aea0d3cb087ce3c41f1a040f0df28e8a4)

When the points that make up $\overline{PQ}$  are reflected over the line $y=x$, they travel in a direction perpendicular to the line and appear the same distance from the line on the other side.

Note that in the case of reflection over the line $y=x$, every point $(a,b)$ is reflected onto an image point  $(b,a)$.

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/bd62a9e7998e5bb44990c179630661f5aa22be07)

Reflecting over the line $y=x$ maps $\overline{PQ}$ onto the blue line below.

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/6936631dcd1cfb7923f23719b583c0358e3f54b4)

*□□□□ □□ □□□□□ □□□□ □□□□□ □□□□□□□□□□ □□□□□□□□□□□?  □□□□□ □□□ [□□□□ □□□□□](□/□□□□□-□□□□□□□□□□-□□□□).*

options.explanation:
In an equation in the form $y=mx + b$:  
$b$ = the $y$ intercept   
$m$ = the slope of the line

**□□□□□□□□:**

$y = x$:  the $y$ intercept is $0$ and the slope is $1$  
$y = -2$: the $y$ intercept is $-2$ and  the slope is $0$.  This  is a horizontal line.  
$x = 1$:  there is no $y$ intercept and the slope is undefined. This is a vertical line.

gradedGroups.content:
**Plot the image of triangle $\triangle ABC$ under a reflection across the $y$-axis.**

[[☃ interactive-graph 1]]

hint.content:
A reflection moves a point perpendicularly across a line, so that the [[☃ definition 1]] is the same distance from the line as the [[☃ definition 2]], but on the other side.

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/fb6f2a256ffa7c13a7d13924c1f960a57fd7be6a)

□□ □□□□□ □□□□□, □□□ □□□□ □□ □□□□□□□□□□ □□ □□□ □□□□□□□□□□□□□ □□□□□□□□ □□□□□□□ □□□ □□□□ □□ □□□□□□□□□□□□□ □□□□□□ □□ □□□ □□□□□ □□□ □□□ □□□-□□□□□.

Since the $y$-axis is *vertical*, the reflection will move each point of $\triangle ABC$ *horizontally* across the axis.

For example, point $A$ is $2$ units to the right of the $y$-axis, so $A'$ will be $2$ units to the left of the axis.

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/8586236c77827c64d829ab9f18c6768530dfb63c)

[[☃ interactive-graph 1]]

hint.content:
A reflection moves a point perpendicularly across a line, so that the [[☃ definition 1]] is the same distance from the line as the [[☃ definition 2]], but on the other side.

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/fb6f2a256ffa7c13a7d13924c1f960a57fd7be6a)

□□ □□□□□ □□□□□, □□□ □□□□ □□ □□□□□□□□□□ □□ □□□ □□□□□□□□□□□□□ □□□□□□□□ □□□□□□□ □□□ □□□□ □□ □□□□□□□□□□□□□ □□□□□□ □□ □□□ □□□□□ □□□ □□□ □□□-□□□□□.

gradedGroups.content:
**Draw the line of reflection that reflects quadrilateral $ABCD$ onto quadrilateral $A'B'C'D'$.**

[[☃ interactive-graph 1]]

hint.content:
A reflection moves a point perpendicularly across a line, so that the [[☃ definition 1]] is the same distance from the line as the [[☃ definition 2]], but on the other side.

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/270f0d877f3e9052561ac6008bac842415c2e9a2)

□□□□ □□□□□ □□□□ □□□ □□□□ □□ □□□□□□□□□□ □□ □□□ □□□□ □□□□ □□□□□□□□ □□□ □□□□□□□□□ □□□□□□□ □□□□□□□□□□□□□ □□□□□□ □□ □□□ □□□-□□□□□ □□□ □□□□□.

□□ □□□□□ □□□□ □□□ □□□□□ □□ □□□□□□□□□□□□□ □□□□□□ □□ □□□□ □□ □□□□ □□□ □□□□ □□ □□□□□□□□□□. 

First, let's find the midpoint between $\blueD{A(-2,1)}$ and $\maroonD{A'(-6,1)}$.

$\left( \dfrac{\blueD{-2}+\maroonD{(-6)}}{2}, \dfrac{\blueD{1}+\maroonD{1}}{2}\right)=(-4,1)$

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/7180f00bdcad76f5421524ecf9246c03f3491ed2)

We can see that the corresponding points would connect with a *horizontal* line segment. The line of reflection is perpendicular to that segment, so the line of reflection must be the *vertical* line that passes through $(-4,1)$.

Alternatively, we can find the midpoint of another pair of corresponding points. For example, the midpoint of $\blueD{C(-3,-6)}$ and $\maroonD{C'(-5,-6)}$ is $(-4,-6)$, so the line of reflection passes through $(-4,1)$ and $(-4,-6)$.

The line $x=-4$ reflects quadrilateral $ABCD$ onto quadrilateral $A'B'C'D'$.

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/f4065f487f0436f28a26d7fe9c6ee35f24d9efb5)
